last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Instapot Vegetable soup
4lbs potatoes chopped
3lb bag of mixed vegetables
3.5 boxes of vegetable stock
2 medium onions chopped doesn't have to be finely chopped just make sure its chopped
3 stalks of celery chopped same thing
1.5 cup of canned tomato sauce
1tbsp garlic powder
1tbsp black pepper
.5 tbsp of Italian seasoning
5 bay leaves

Now you have delicious rich, peppery, savory potato vegetable soup for 4 days lunch and dinner under $10

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Use a pyrex bowl anon. But the microwave is a good way to cook rice, perhaps even optimal if you take into account time savings.

I just fill the container so the water is one index finger joint above the level of the rice. Loosely cover with lid, and make sure to put the container into another to catch boilover. Then high for 13 mins in the microwave.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18686564
Not that anon, but we have:
>Bocadillo
A confectionary made out of red guava paste mixed with sugar and brought to a boil. They have it in Venezuela and Brazil (Goiabada) as well, but we have one (veleño) made with both red and white guava fruit and packed in bijao leaves.
>Ajiaco
A soup made with several types of potatoes, usually Papa Nevada, Capira and Criolla, chicken, corncob and seasoning; basically, you make stock with chicken cuts like breasts or drumsticks and get a thick soup by cooking in it the aforementioned ingredients. People add chopped huasca leaves to give it "it's proper flavor" but I think that shit is rank.
>Buñuelos
Different from the mexican ones, these are cheese fritters made with queso costeño (a dryer, saltier version of Queso Blanco), cornstarch, eggs, sugar, water and a bit of mandioca/yucca starch. You mix it all, you get cheese balls you dump into hot oil and you take them out when brown.
You can find them all the year on cafeterias and bakeries but they are more related to christmas time, served with natilla (a sort of pudding made with cornstarch and panela — a hard paste made out of cane sugar) and hojuelas, which are mexican buñuelos.
There's many out there and most are shared with our neighbouring countries or are very exclusive to certain regions: Hormigas culonas, Cuy asado, Lechona, Morcilla (yes, the spanish blood sausage), Tamal (think of the mexican one, but wrapped in green plantain leaves), the different types of arepas and the eternal debate of whether the colombians or venezuelans are the best ones, etc.

com: any idea why the cream cheese turned blue?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
There are several reasons why cream cheese may turn blue. One common cause is the presence of bacteria, such as Penicillium, which can produce blue or greenish-blue pigments. These bacteria are often found in refrigerated foods, especially those that have been stored for a long time or have been exposed to air.

Another possible cause of blue cream cheese is the presence of a natural blue pigment called tyrosine. This pigment is produced by some bacteria and can be found in foods such as cheese, yogurt, and other fermented dairy products.

While the blue color in cream cheese may seem unusual or unappealing, it is actually a sign of healthy bacterial activity. The presence of these bacteria indicates that the cream cheese is being properly fermented, which helps to preserve its flavor and improve its nutritional value.

In general, cream cheese that has turned blue is still safe to eat.

com:
I'm in the US visiting relatives and I finally understand why Americans are so fat.

It's the amount of choice and variety. If you go to the frozen foods section of a supermarket in Europe for example the selection is pretty humble. If you go to the US it's just freezer and freezer of a million different no-effort meals that are actually pretty good. I bought frozen gyoza, empenadas and a bunch of other shit and it's all at least decent.

There's a million different types of ice creams and flavors. There's a seemingly infinite number of cereals, chips, snacks, spreads, cheeses, deli meats, steak cuts. I walked in the other day and I was genuinely overwhelmed by the sheer amount of choice.

If I lived in the US there is a high chance I'd be buying easy-to-prepare half ready meals and not put much effort into vegetables or eating normally.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18687008
Around 60% or more hydration, im blending bread flour and whole wheat rn cause I like the consistency and I'd like to think it's a bit healthier. I put my flour in with a good bit of yeast, bit less sugar, salt, then put in water and olive oil and knead.
Don't really measure or anything just have a sense after a few tries how much of each.
I had been working on my dough a couple years ago but I just started running the pizza stone and it has changed the game entirely.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18687050
Also began experimenting with my own sauce. Amazingly found d.o.p. certified San marzano tomatoes in my small town grocery store. Did a simple neapolitan with uncooked sauce to get a real taste for them and was really impressed.
Going to try cooking next time.
For seasonings you can never go wrong with lots of garlic, whatever generic Italian seasoning, and crushed chili flakes for heat. Plus obviously salt but always account for how much is in each component (ie in your dough, how much olive oil you use, and the glutamate content of your toppings).
Parmesan under the mozzarella, parm has glutamate, mushrooms if you use those. You can even put msg into your dough but I haven't got any on hand atm.
Pizza is very personal and cooking your own and experimenting is the best way to find what qualities you really like in your pie.

Apart from French, Italian, Greek and Spanish most European food is bland, weird fish shit or potatoes and cabbage because that's typically all there was to eat in those countries in the past. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18686516
Start with a gallon of unpasteurized whole milk. Heat to just below boiling. Stir in half a cup of fresh squeezed lemon juice and a big pinch of salt. Allow small curds to form, then strain through cheesecloth until dry enough to be spreadable.
Brown one pound hot Italian sausage, one pound ground veal, and a few ounces of chorizo in batches. Remove as it browns. Add finely diced onion, shallot, celery, and carrot. Big pinch of salt, copious amounts of black pepper, two bay leaves, oregano, rosemary, thyme, and marjoram in as well. Cook until most of the moisture is gone. Add a quarter cup of tomato paste and plenty of crushed garlic. Cook until almost burned. Deglaze with a dry white wine. Add two cans san marzano tomatoes, the browned meat, and enough beef stock to keep everything moist. Cook uncovered until the sauce reduces to a very thick consistency.
Make a pasta dough with 400g flour and 2 eggs plus 4 yolks plus enough water to bring the dough together. Roll into thin sheets and trim with a fluted wheel.
Make a bechamel with 1 cup butter, 1 cup flour, and 2.5 cups whole milk. Finish with a grating of nutmeg.
Parboil the noodles in heavily salted water. Drain them well on a rack or tea towel.
Assemble the lasagna in layers. Bolognese, noodle, bechamel, ricotta, repeat. Grate a generous amount of pecorino romano over the top. Cover with foil. Bake at 350 for 45 minutes. Remove the foil and continue baking 15 minutes. Broil on high at the end to finish browning the top if needed.
Rest for 30 minutes and serve.
